  physical_appearance: This is a watercolour painting of the artist\u0027s depiction of Lim Bo Seng working at the Bukit Bidor campsite. The painting shows the back view of a man
 sitting on a stump. He is dressed in a white singlet
 and is shown bent over working on something. In the background
 there is another man working on the ground. There is a faded Chinese text inscription on the bottom-left of the painting.

  sgcool_label_text: This drawing belongs to part of a collection of artefacts related to the World War II underground resistance movement known as Force 136. The collection of materials was gathered by Tan Chong Tee (1916- 2012)
 who was a key member of this resistance group. The collection consists of original materials belonging to Tan and other members of Force 136 dating from the 1940s to new materials reproduced from memory by Tan Chong Tee
 which date from mid 1990s to early 2000s. \r\n\r\nForce 136 was set up in July 1942 as part of the British Special Operations Executive (SOE). It recruited and trained local guerrillas to gather intelligence and create an underground spy network to support planned British invasion of Japanese-occupied Malaya.\r\n\r\nThis drawing depicts the anti-Japanese war hero
 Lim Bo Seng (1909-1944) at work at the Bukit Bidor Campsite.

metadata.physical_appearance: This is a watercolour painting of the artist's depiction of Lim Bo Seng working at the Bukit Bidor campsite. The painting shows the back view of a man, sitting on a stump. He is dressed in a white singlet, and is shown bent over working on something. In the background, there is another man working on the ground. There is a faded Chinese text inscription on the bottom-left of the painting.

metadata.sgcool_label_text:
This drawing belongs to part of a collection of artefacts related to the World War II underground resistance movement known as Force 136. The collection of materials was gathered by Tan Chong Tee (1916- 2012), who was a key member of this resistance group. The collection consists of original materials belonging to Tan and other members of Force 136 dating from the 1940s to new materials reproduced from memory by Tan Chong Tee, which date from mid 1990s to early 2000s. 

Force 136 was set up in July 1942 as part of the British Special Operations Executive (SOE). It recruited and trained local guerrillas to gather intelligence and create an underground spy network to support planned British invasion of Japanese-occupied Malaya.

This drawing depicts the anti-Japanese war hero, Lim Bo Seng (1909-1944) at work at the Bukit Bidor Campsite.
